Cell.Data: Your basic, run-of-the-mill ballistic pistol, Commander. Mass-produced and readily available, things used to die when you pointed one of these at them....until those things stopped being people and started being aliens, anyways. Give one of these to your shield-handlers so they feel like they're part of the team...and don't try to dual-wield them. That's just childish.

Fairly basic, Sir. The ballistic shotgun fires a handful of heavy lead pellets in the general direction it's facing. While dangerous to us, we aren't sure how effective these pellets will be against the enemy armour...or hide, or whatever. Regardless, shotguns work best when used up-close, so have your soldiers get in there, Commander!

Here we are Sir, the ballistic rifle. Moderate range, moderate stopping power, moderate accuracy, this weapon is exceptional only in being average. It can be fired in a three-shot burst, should your soldier have enough time to line it up, but that's about it. If your soldiers have more enthusiasm than accuracy, use these.

If you need to reach out and touch something at a distance, this will be your tool of choice. Longer-ranged than the rifle, and harder-hitting, this precision rifle can make the most of your soldier's accuracy....if they have any, anyways. No burst-fire option on this gun, unfortunately, so you better make those precious few shots count.

This heavy machinegun is what defined the phrase “spray and pray”, and that's exactly what you should expect when you use it, though it isn't as easy to use as some of our other weapons. Firstly, the heavy machinegun is exactly what it says...HEAVY. You'd better have a rather brawny soldier carry this thing, or they won't be able to hold it still while it's firing. Second, it takes a few minutes to set this weapon up prior to firing...extending the legs, inserting the clip, bracing the weapon...which means that there's no time to be running around. If you make a soldier move prior to firing a heavy weapon like this, expect your accuracy to drop significantly. You've been warned!

The rocket launcher itself is a simple tube with a basic aiming apparatus and a triggering system...it's the rockets themselves that are interesting. So long as they adhere to the specifications for rocket ammunition, we will be able to fire them with this system. Who knows what amazing rockets we will develop as we backwards-engineer the alien technology? Speaking of alien technology, you should be aware that explosions tend not to leave intact hardware behind, so if you're hoping to recover any of the alien goodies you may want to steer clear of explosive ammunition.

Infantry laser weapons previously existed only in the realms of science fiction. Any laser powerful enough to be a viable combat weapon would need a battery the size of a truck - the word "impractical" being an understatement.
The arrival of alien technology has changed all of this. The enormous energy content of an Alenium crystal allows a battery no larger than a standard ammunition magazine to generate up to a dozen laser beams, each capable of burning through an inch of steel. Superconducting ceramics can be used to cool the weapon, storing the waste heat from each shot and dissipating slowly enough to avoid injury (provided one is careful where they place their hands). This eliminates the need for bulky refrigeration units, reducing the size and weight of the weapons significantly.
In order to minimise adjustment time for our troops, our laser weapons have been designed to operate like conventional firearms and have similar range and accuracy to their predecessors. There are some notable differences, most obviously the improved damage thermal shock weapons inflict upon their targets. Less favourably, a laser weapon will have roughly half the ammunition capacity of a ballistic weapon. In order to streamline this process, we have designed a single standardised battery for all of our laser weapons. The design is not complex; a cylindrical steel jacket that contains an Alenium crystal and locks into the weapon with a simple twist. These power cells are trivial to manufacture compared to the weapons themselves, so are available in effectively unlimited quantities.
Be aware that manufacturing these weapons consumes a large amount of alien alloys and is both expensive and time consuming - but I still believe they represent a good investment despite this. At the very least, some new toys may raise morale amongst your men. Laser pistol is the beginning of the energy weapon era. Consider that, this weapons are not more powerful then our first ballistic weapons, they are just good against aliens with ballistic resistances.
Short range energy burst laser. Very low ranged but has good power.
Assault rifle powered by energy cells.

One of your engineers recently presented me with an idea for a rapid-fire laser weapon. Though it is (predictably) expressed crudely, the fundamental science appears sound.
The ideal approach would be to generate a continuous beam of energy that can be "swept" across the battlefield, but even alien superconductors are not capable of dissipating the amount of heat generated by sustained continuous fire. The proposed solution borrows heavily from the Autocannon mounted on our interceptors - multiple rotating barrels. Instead of using a rotating barrel arrangement to facilitate high-speed loading of ammunition, it can be used to vastly reduce the amount of heat continual fire will generate in each individual barrel. We have successfully tested two three-barrel prototype weapons in our laboratories.
The Scatter Laser is a rapid-fire infantry weapon designed to replace the ballistic Machinegun. It inflicts increased damage and suppression, at the cost of reduced ammunition capacity. Unfortunately, it still suffers "recoil" (albeit in this case caused by the spinning of the heavy cooling arrays rather than the recoil of the projectiles) and therefore will require a strong soldier to achieve full accuracy with this weapon.
The Gatling Laser is scaled up to fit the cannon hardpoint on our interceptors, using a triangular arrangement of three powerful lasers that collectively inflict much greater damage than the conventional Autocannon. The increased size and weight of the weapon allows us to use mostly conventional materials in the construction of the weapon and its power cell, paradoxically making them far easier and faster to manufacture than their smaller cousins. As such, we have already upgraded our existing Autocannons to the new design - the only difference you should see is increased combat effectiveness.

Studying the innards of the alien Plasma Pistol and Plasma Rifle has given us a basic understanding of the science behind extraterrestrial directed energy weapons. We remain some distance from replicating plasma-based weapons ourselves, even in a laboratory setting, but our work raises the tantalising possibility of battlefield laser weapons.
A brief explanation of the generation of a plasma bolt is as follows: firstly, the weapon draws power from an Alenium cell and uses it to fuel a powerful array of particle accelerators. Secondly, these accelerators superheat a large number of atoms into a state of ionised gas within the heat-proofed 'chamber' of the weapon. Thirdly, two helical spirals of electromagnets in the barrel of the weapon pulse simultaneously, drawing the plasma from the chamber and spinning it into a bolt while accelerating it to muzzle velocity. Finally, a graviton emitter in the muzzle of the weapon launches a graviton particle into the plasma bolt as it exits the barrel.
This graviton particle is incredibly important - in laboratory conditions, it has been observed to possess a strong gravitational pull that prevents the bolt from dissipating into a useless cloud of hot gas. The science behind this process is unclear (it is the first time we have observed a graviton), but it probably explains the large difference in range between the alien Plasma Pistol and Plasma Rifle. Sadly, we have no idea of how to replicate this gravitational field ourselves - and without access to an effective anti-gravity emitter, the useful range of our most powerful lab-based plasma generator is only a few inches. One would hope that study of the more advanced alien weapons may shed more light on the process.
In the meantime, our efforts would be better focused on the development of battlefield laser technology. We have learned enough from studying the power distribution and cooling systems of the alien weapons that I believe I can replicate them in our own designs, making building man-portable laser weapons from these new alien materials a theoretical possibility.

The aliens have added an electron injection current into their plasma devices. As you recall, plasma weaponry functions by compressing ionized gas in a magnetic container. The field is then oscillated to produce spin and heat by friction, then morphed to launch the contents. What the aliens have done is add electron injection relays which produce currents within the gas, charging it rapidly and producing heat. The plasma forms in the barrel quickly and is superheated. Thankfully, there are upsides to this alarming change in strategy. The plasma weapon requires more time to cool as a result of the superheating, meaning that the enemy rate of fire is the same. While each shot of theirs has more destructive potential, our soldiers tend not to survive a single hit even by ordinary weapons. It also indicates that we are being taken seriously-a mixed blessing, but strangely gratifying. We can also use this innovation in our own weaponry if we recover electron relays for study. I’m sure our men in the field are looking forward to revenge.

Key Information: 5 Weapons for 2 energy core
The Plasma Pistol is an alien sidearm that is approximately eight inches long and roughly a kilogram in weight. Though it bears some resemblance to a human firearm, it does not fire a bullet but rather a searing bolt of superheated plasma.
It is a powerful weapon, easily capable of killing an unarmoured man in a single shot. However, our tests suggest the compact size of the weapon renders it fairly inefficient: the plasma bolt loses cohesion and starts to dissipate almost immediately. It is thus most dangerous at short ranges, where a single shot has a good chance of killing one of our soldiers outright. As that range increases, the projectile steadily becomes less accurate and damaging. The lesson here should be clear: fight units equipped with this weapon from as far away as possible.
Though it would make a fine addition to our arsenal, this weapon has clearly been designed for alien troops. Anatomical differences between our species make it difficult for a human to wield effectively, so any soldier attempting to use this weapon on the battlefield will suffer severe accuracy penalties when doing so. Sadly, we are also nowhere near understanding or replicating the technology contained within the weapon (recovering more advanced alien weapons may help in that regard). All is not lost, however - running more tests on this weapon should allow us to develop battlefield infantry armour better suited to protecting our men from extraterrestrial energy weapons.

Key Information: 2 Weapons for 1 energy core
The alien Assault Plasma is a two-handed alien infantry weapon roughly twenty-eight inches in length and five kilograms in weight. Though it employs a different method of operation, it acts much like a shotgun in effect: it spits multiple "pellets" of deadly plasma at the target.
These "pellets" are, of course, nothing of the sort. Each is an individual bolt of plasma fired from one of the weapon's three entirely separate barrels. The device employs a particularly large generation array, which allows all three of the barrels to simultaneously discharge a bolt of plasma that is almost as powerful as the bolt fired by the alien Plasma Rifle. This makes the weapon highly dangerous at short range: if all three shots strike the same target, it is unlikely to survive the experience.
Thankfully, this weapon is inaccurate, has mediocre armour penetration and a very limited range - it does not appear to utilise the standard graviton emitter seen on other alien weapons at all. Tackle enemies wielding this weapon at distance, as it relies on proximity rather than precision.

Key Information: 2 Weapons for 1 energy core.
The alien Plasma Rifle is a two-handed alien infantry weapon approximately thirty inches in length and three kilograms in weight. It is a vastly more capable combat weapon than the alien Plasma Pistol, generating a plasma bolt that is significantly more powerful and cohesive than its smaller cousin.
Without the space constraints of the Plasma Pistol, the aliens have mounted a more substantial generation array inside the weapon's barrel. This gives it a similar operational range to most ballistic assault rifles, but far higher damage and armour penetration potential. Laboratory tests suggest Jackal combat armour may do just enough to allow the wearer to survive a direct hit, but unarmoured troops would likely be killed instantly. Indeed, we believe this weapon is even a credible threat to our Hunter armoured cars.
It would appear that the versatility of the alien Plasma Rifle makes it the default armament for alien combatants. It is powerful, light, accurate and capable of burst fire - in short, vastly superior to anything we possess.
Key Information: 2 Weapons for 1 energy core.

Key Information: 1 Weapons for 1 energy core.
The alien Precision Plasma is an extraterrestrial infantry weapon that measures nearly fifty inches in length. It is fitted with a complex holographic sighting array and produces a focused bolt of plasma that travels extremely quickly and can maintain stability over great range, suggesting it is the alien equivalent of a sniper rifle.
The weapon has remarkable internal similarities to the Heavy Plasma, possessing the same lengthened generation chamber that significantly amplifies the energy content of the resulting bolt. The main difference lies with the helical spiral of electromagnets housed in the barrel of the weapon: long and thin, rather than short and compact. This results in a narrow and stretched bolt of plasma that can carve through the air with less resistance (and destabilisation) than normal, and then focus a great deal of energy into a narrower impact point to give more penetrative power.
This fearsome penetrative power is actually somewhat of a mixed blessing. The plasma bolts will punch through almost any concievable type of armour, but will also punch right through the soldier underneath. While I doubt having a tunnel half an inch wide burned straight through your body is a particularly pleasant experience, it is unlikely to be fatal unless it strikes the brain or another vital organ. This weapon therefore presents an interesting conundrum: it is very accurate even at long range and will bypass any protective equipment the target may be wearing, but it also fires slowly and is unlikely to kill a soldier outright.

Key Information: 1 Weapons for 1 energy core
The alien Plasma Cannon is a large infantry weapon that measures a little less than fifty inches in length. We believe it is best thought of as the alien equivalent of a bazooka or rocket-propelled grenade, firing a single powerful bolt of plasma that has great range and will inflict major damage on anything caught in the blast radius.
It is vastly superior to its conventional counterparts. The most obvious advantage is the increased damage it inflicts: at short range it can penetrate at least 15 inches of solid steel (precise measurements were difficult as we ran out of steel before the projectile ran out of power). In basic terms, it is enough to destroy virtually any conventional vehicle in the world in a single shot. Also important is the ammunition capacity of the weapon - it takes even a skilled operator up to ten seconds to reload a traditional anti-tank weapon after every shot, while the alien Plasma Cannon can draw four shots from its battery before it must be changed. The weapon also suffers minimal recoil and has no back-blast, making it easier to handle and safer for adjacent friendly units.
Thankfully, alien materials are far more resistant against the penetrative effect of these projectiles than conventional materials. We believe the vaporised metal forms a shell around the projectile when it strikes steel, doing much of the penetrating work for it. However, the higher melting point of alien alloys prevents this from occurring and instead the projectile must rely on raw energy to inflict damage. Our more advanced technology gives us some protection against this weapon - though the Wolf and Buzzard are not strong enough to protect a soldier from a direct hit, the Wolf in particular should help our troops survive being caught in the blast. I have already warned your men about the fearsome power of this weapon; one hopes it will encourage them to get out of the way of the projectiles.

Key Information: 1 Weapon for 2 energy cores
The Alien Battle Rifle is an alien weapon around forty inches long and five kilogrammes in weight. It can project deadly bolts of plasma over great distance with incredible accuracy, is capable of burst fire and has excellent armour mitigation. Be very careful of enemies carrying this weapon - not only do they have access to the most fearsome weapon in the extraterrestrial arsenal, they will also represent the elite of the alien forces.
The Battle Rifle is the finest example of a plasma weapon we are likely to encounter. The engineering is extremely impressive: there is little to differentiate the workings of the Battle Rifle from other alien weapons beyond the quality of production. Virtually every component shows dozens of incremental improvements: for example, every electromagnet in the weapon has a hardened alloy core that has undergone complete electron rearrangement, allowing them to generate a charge twice as powerful as normal. It would probably take us years to replicate just one of these weapons.
We would do well to clone this design, but we could also do better still. Although we have witnessed first-hand how devastating plasma technology can be, it still suffers from inherent limitations - studying every example of Alien Weapons may just give us enough the knowledge we need to develop a new category of weapons that surpasses them entirely.
Alien long range neutron weapons. -Waiting Lore-

We have been studying captured alien plasma weapons from the very start of the war, but have always lacked enough understanding of the technology to weaponise it effectively. However in recent times we have come close enough that we can bridge the gap using the favoured technique of the intellectually deficient: imitation. This has allowed us to build a functioning copy of the graviton emitter that had stymied our progress up to this point.
Given our detailed understanding of the plasma accelerator that converts the energy into a plasma bolt and the electromagnet spiral that shapes the bolt, we were able to use trial and error until we stumbled onto a working configuration of the three components. Small adjustments to the relative scale and distance between these three components allows us to generate plasma bolts with subtly different properties, thus producing different weapons. These plasma weapons are a straightforward upgrade for our existing laser weapons, inflicting heavier damage whilst maintaining similar range and accuracy. In most other respects, they behave much like their predecessors.
Finally, I discovered recently that the Nobel Prize panel does not disqualify submissions if the scientific advances in question have been stolen from extraterrestrials rather than humans. I estimate I am now owed at least six of them and would greatly appreciate it if you could use these new Plasma weapons to keep Stockholm safe until the end of the war. This pistol is the first step as a sidearm.

Plasma rifle. Short range but good damage.
Even its a sniper rifle, its range is not so much but can take on shot many enemies.

We now have Plasma variants of our generic infantry weapons such as pistols and rifles, but we are still lacking an equivalent for high rate-of-fire weapons such as the machinegun or interceptor autocannon. The infantry-portable Plasma Caster and the more substantial aircraft-mounted Plasma Blaster have been designed to fill this void.
They work on similar principles. Both expel large amounts of plasma in the form of a sustained stream, utilising a large generation array that continually discharges superheated plasma. In ordinary conditions it would be difficult to focus this stream and it would dissipate quickly, giving it short range and poor armour penetration. However, we have solved this problem by employing a ring of five graviton generators around the muzzle of the weapon. These fire sequentially, regularly injecting gravitons into the plasma and breaking the stream up into a string of individual projectiles.
This effect replicates the high rate-of-fire of conventional automatic weapons and combines it with the extra damage of a plasma weapon. Both should make useful upgrades in our fight against the extraterrestrials.

Key Information: 1 Weapon for 1 ballistic core

As improving our plasma technology to the point where it surpassed that of the aliens would be virtually impossible, new ideas were needed. They arrived in the form of old ideas. MAG weapons are electromagnetic coilguns that combine the remarkable properties of alien materials with our existing knowledge of ballistic weapons.
The idea behind a Gauss gun / coilgun has been around for over a century and consists of a series of electromagnets firing sequentially, accelerating a projectile along the barrel of the weapon to deadly speeds. The parallels with alien plasma weapons should be obvious - but while the plasma technology uses the electromagnetic acceleration as a means to an end, a coilgun uses it as a means in itself. The technology can be adapted from existing plasma weapon designs and has some significant advantage, e.g. an energy projectile does mostly thermal damage and can be partially absorbed / reflected / dissipated by a number of factors, atmospheric conditions included. A spot of rain will not offer much protection against a metal pellet travelling at five times the speed of sound.
MAG weapon prototypes have been built in Pistol, Shotgun, Rifle and Precision arrangements, each one small enough to be carried by an infantryman but still capable of delivering a pellet of alien alloy at hypersonic speed. They are almost certainly the most powerful terrestrial infantry weapons that will ever exist - pushing muzzle velocity any higher would raise air resistance highly enough to explosively ignite the air behind the projectile (likely killing the soldier firing the weapon). It seems we are now limited by the composition of our atmosphere rather than by our technology. So this is the sidearm pistol.

It is pleasing to be working with kinetic weapons again; humans have been using them for thousands of years and I feel we have developed a certain affinity with them. The intricacies of MAG technology are extremely complex and dramatically different from those of ballistic weapons, but there are still basic principles that can be carried between the two.
The rotary barrel arrangement is one, having served us well even for our rapid-fire energy weapons. We have adapted it for one final use: the MAGSTORM, a devastating weapon capable of annihilating a target in a hail of hypersonic projectiles. It consists of four rotating barrels, each of which has an electromagnetic spiral that is wound twice as tightly as on a standard MAG weapon. This could be used to impart more force on a projectile, but instead the weapon is set up so that each bullet uses only half of the coil. This allows each barrel to accelerate two bullets simultaneously, giving eight times the normal fire rate with no loss of stopping power.
This technology is equally effective when using small-calibre infantry ammunition or large-calibre aircraft munitions. It represents the ultimate in rapid-fire weaponry; I'm sure your men will be keen to get their hands on them.

Key Information: 1 Weapon for 1 chemical core
The Alien Blood Pistol is a fourteen-inch chemical weapon that resembles a watergun toy . It produces high pressure globules of an acutely toxic and caustic red liquid nicknamed “Blood,” firing either smaller droplet-clouds in bursts or larger, more accurate globules. The Alien Blood Pistol is capable of killing armoured soldiers within minutes. Thankfully its size renders it fairly inaccurate, though still far more accurate than human water guns. It is easy to understand why only the reptilian Sebillians wield this weapon-the heat continuously generated by the warmers that keep Blood alive causes first degree burns and sore palms after prolonged contact. The fact that no other race we have encountered uses this weapon merits further study. Our soldiers understandably refuse to come into contact with this weapon except with absolutely necessary. Blood has an alarming habit of sloshing around within the containment tanks it is stored in, giving the impression that it is actively trying to escape.

Key Information: 1 Weapon for 2 chemical cores
The Alien Blood Rifle is a medium-sized anti-personnel chemical gun. It fires high pressure bursts of a toxic and caustic liquid “Blood” like its smaller relative the Alien Blood Pistol, but is far more accurate and deadly. With far more space available for the fluid launching mechanism, it can fire droplets at speeds almost impossible to avoid. Where it was possible for a running soldier to breeze right past a shot from an Alien Blood Pistol, evading the Alien Blood Rifle requires peak reflexes. It is fortunately incapable of producing continuous streams, instead launching high pressure globules or droplet-clouds depending on the pressure a hand applies to the weapon. The speed of a Blood bullet is equal to a fastball pitched by the average top-level baseball star, but is significantly more lethal. While the kinetic energy delivered by the small splashes of fluid are merely enough to bruise, the alkaline liquid is poisonous and infectious. We’ve seen signs of immune system activity in soldiers exposed to doses of this weapon. Until we complete our tests on the effects of this bio-chemical nightmare, do not expose your soldiers to Blood any more than you can help it.

The Shock Pistol is yet another boon from our reasearch into the alien shock weaponry, and I can't tell you how excited I am to finally have these new toys to play with. You've seen them being used against us in the form of the alien lightning weapons, and I dare say they've been rather effective at making our soldiers crumple to the ground unconscious. I can see why they'd want to use this kind of technology, too... we can't be the only ones wanting to learn about our enemy from the enemy themselves. This is an elegant way to go about it as well... our soldiers have been limited to either melee stun weapons or weak stun grenades until now. They work... but not that well, and winding up standing near an ALMOST-stunned alien while being too tired for further movement hasn't exactly been ideal for soldier morale. Now we can stun them from a distance, from behind cover...heck, from behind a shield too, even... and that's going to make our alien capture operations so much easier. What's that Commander, how do they work? Well, they actually operate on a rather simple idea that was maddeningly difficult to actually put into practice. What we found from the Caesan lightning guns was that they were using a focused UV laser to ionize a small trail of atmospheric particles, creating a small, temporary path from weapon to target that could be followed by a high-voltage current. They generate such a current with the miniaturized alenium reactor housed within the weapon itself, the ammo being little more than small spheres of alenium used to replenish the reactor's fuel supply. In essence, the Caesan's have recreated how our clouds form lighning bolts with their technology... quite impressive. And now, so have I, and I didn't even need the resources of an entire alien invasion fleet to do it. Good thing I'm on your side isn't it, Commander? Do keep in mind that this is only the first version of this weapon technology, though. It's not that powerful.
Short range shock rifle. Good for capturing alive and against robotic aliens.
Long range shock sniper rifle. Highly effective for capturing alive and against robotic aliens.
Long range shock cannon. Highly effective for capturing alive and against robotic aliens.

Ah, the flamethrower, truly the definition of the horror of war....but for once, not aimed at human targets! That feels like progress, for some reason, though we aren't really sure how useful it will be against the alien invasion. You need to get close to the enemy to use this weapon, Commander, even closer than the shotgun. I'm sure your soldiers are going to be very excited to be mere feet away from the enemy while they try to light him on fire, and with that in mind it may be prudent to give this weapon to your more...expendable... soldiers. On a more positive note, once they are close they should find it extremely difficult to miss their target! Let's just hope that the alien is dead by the time the flames die down, or it's going to be rather...unhappy.
Plasma tanks and plasma flames. Burn them all!!!

C4 is such a stable explosive... it won't go off if you drop it, or even if you light it on fire, which is exactly why I chose to give it to those cretins in the barracks for use on their missions. Now, I should mention that we have no idea how effective it's going to be as a weapon, seeing as we know so little about the alien's ability to withstand explosive shockwaves, so you're going to have to lob a few their way and report back. I do mean lob, Commander... you aren't going to want to be anywhere near an exploding C4 charge, I assure you. We may not know the alien resistances, but we sure as heck know what the human resistance to explosives is: none. No resistance whatsoever. If one of them manages to arm a C4 charge and then not throw it, or if the don't throw it far enough, BOOM. Dead team. Be very careful should you ever need to toss one of these out the back of one of our troop transports, Commander!

Here's something you should find fun Commander, a bigger, better explosive! It turns out that incorporating the depleted alenium into our explosives really gives us a good bang for our buck... you see what I did there? I'm hilarious! Anyways, it makes our explosives even more powerful, and so I've put together this design for the Alenium Heavy Charge. It's rather simple, as we're just wrapping the existing C4 core with alenium crystals suspended in a resin, but it works well. That's also the major problem with it, Commander...not only will the aliens get blown to pieces, so will any alien technology they happen to be holding. You'll have to make a choice about whether that's worth it, but if your soldiers are facing overwhelming opposition, perhaps it's time to light one of these up. Just make sure it's far enough away when you do, Sir.

Ah, I see you got my message, glad you could make it down to the lab so quickly. I've got something to show you, Commander... I've managed to incorporate our latest breakthrough with the miniaturized alenium reactors into a heavy charge design, with great results. It works in a similar fashion to our other plasma explosives, in that it takes some of the un-spent alenium we've been gathering and uses it to turn the air surrounding the heavy charge into an extremely hot and highly damaging plasma. Very effective at making a desired location into an inhospitable inferno... just make sure that the location you choose doesn't include any of your precious soldiers. I mean that, Commander... one of our technicians was attempting to miniaturize the reactor design even further and managed to create a small plasma fireball a mere meter from his face. I'm never going to get the smell of burnt hair out of my lab, Commander, and it's disgusting!

We've managed to integrate a hydrogen core into our plasma heavy charge, and the Fusion Heavy Charge is the result… and it's just as destructive as we could've hoped, Sir. It works in an identical fashion to our previous heavy charge weapons, though you'll notice the explosion radius is a little wider and the damage considerably heavier. As always, watch our for friendly fire, and never use a heavy charge on things you want to salvage... alien tech reacts poorly to fusion bombs. You'll have to make a choice, Commander, their tech or their lives! Isn't it nice to have that kind of power?
This is the most powerful weapon ever created with this size. Unstable and not tested nearly enough. We really don't know how this charge will react, and the results are all on-paper calculations..

Here's something you may find useful, Commander, an alien shock-tech based heavy charge. It's design is simple, though ingenious, and is composed of two separate alenium sources of which one is wrapped in a few kilograms of powerdered copper. This sphere of alenium is designed to create a small explosion, spreading the copper particles throughout the surrounding air, making the area highly electrically conductive for a few brief moments. The second bit of alenium is intended to power a very small generator array for a very brief time, mere moments actually. It's not particularly efficient, but we don't actually need it to be, as it's sole purpose is to generate a massively high-voltage electrical discharge to take advantage of the now highly-conductive air surrounding the device. Instant sphere of lightning, Sir... isn't that amazing? Now, if you've managed to detonate this thing near a couple of Androns or other agents of mechanical mayhem, you're going to get to see firsthand what electical circuits look like as they melt. On the other hand, biological targets are going to get quite the shock, and only the very strongest are going to be left in any shape to stand, let alone fire a weapon. They won't be dead, just very, very unconscious. It's got a decent radius on it and solid mitigation too, so you won't need to be overly accurate with it. One major warning, though, the Shock Heavy Charge doesn't really care what kind of biological it zaps. If you set the timer on it and forget to throw it expect the soldier holding it and all of his nearby buddies to be unconscious puddles of stupidity in the near future. You've been warned, Commander!

This is the same technology as the EMP grenades and rockets, just upgraded into the heavy charge form. A serious pain to lug into the battlefield, this wonderful little device is going to pay off big time whenever you're trying to breech an Andron-infested UFO wreck. I'm not exagerating, either...because our EMP devices can't hurt our soldiers, we don't have the normal fear surrounding an expanded explosion radius, so we've done everything we can to make it as big as possible. When this thing goes off, you're going to see that we accomplished what we set out to do, and if you happened to catch a bunch mechanical units in that massive blast radius they aren't going to be coming out of it in tip-top shape, I assure you. I highly recommend that you get those lugs down in engineering to put a few together, maybe put a nice ribbon on it so your soldiers know what a gift they're getting with the EMP Heavy Charge. They can thank me later.
By faceting depleted alenium to our alenium grenades, the shards of fragmentation have much more punch. In case your men are wondering, yes, it has the same operating procedures.
Electroshock weapons have existed for quite a while. We've modified a standard cattle prod to be more.. prodding.

The design schematics for the new Power Baton have been uploaded, Commander, and I believe they are going to make stunning and capturing some of the more resilient aliens a whole lot easier. It's operation is based on two formerly-incompatible technologies, advanced focused laser tech and the alien shock weapons tech. Now that we've had a chance to take a closer look at both it was clear that they could be combined into a much more effective stun weapon than we currently had available. To start, the alien shock weapons work by first creating a path of ionized particles through a path in the air, and they do this by using a tightly focused ultra-violet laser beam. It's invisible to the naked eye, and it's purpose isn't to cause damage directly...instead it lays the path down which an incredibly high voltage discharge can go. Essentialy the shock weapons first lay down a path for a lightning bolt, and then send one down. The power baton uses the same idea by generating a number of UV laser beams in the hollow handle of the weapon facing towards the top. I've mounted a very carefully designed refractor in the top of the baton, and it's job is to not only reflect those beams ourward at the head of the weapon, but to also narrow the focus of those beams down to a single point over the range of 20 centimeters or so. Once this halo of UV lasers has ionized the surrounding air, a high-voltage electical discharge can be triggered via a button on the exterior of the baton which will travel down the ionization trails to the focal points created by the refractor. From there, the "lightning " will arc towards whatever isn't properly shielded...hopefully an alien, but possibly the operator of the Power Baton if they were stupid enough to forget the protective gauntlet that I'm supplying with the weapon. We'll see. In any case, I believe you'll find this Power Baton to be much more effective at it's stunning duties than the old shock baton was, so you may want to get engineering to start cooking some up. Have fun with your game of alien whack-a-mole, Commander.
A crude knife created from chiseled chitin. Still cuts through most conventional materials like butter.
With more material and experience, we can make a longer and sharper blade.
Chitin axe, crudely cut. Provides good leverage for hacking through materials.
Using a molding process, we are able to achieve a sharper edge at the cost of extra material.

The Assault Shield is a direct upgrade for the Combat Shield, employing our new knowledge of hardened alien alloys to create a tactical shield with much improved durability. It functions in the same way as its predecessor - soaking up most of the incoming damage from targets in front of the user.
The vastly improved ballistic and thermal resistance of hardened alien alloys make them much more effective at stopping incoming damage. As fabricating a rectangle is not a difficult task, the main point of debate was over whether we should design a lighter and less cumbersome shield or leave the weight unchanged and greatly increase protection. Discussion with your men revealed they had an overwhelming preference for the latter, and given the brief life expectancy of your breaching soldiers I was inclined to agree with them. The Assault Shield should be able to withstand several hits from most alien plasma weapons before failing, hopefully enough to get the user through a mission without serious injury.
The Assault Shield does, of course, fill one of the soldier's hands. Unable to wield two-handed weapons, they will be forced to use a pistol. You should also be aware that our shields do not provide complete protection; there is always a small chance that a lucky shot will hit an exposed body-part.

You're not going to believe this, Commander, but I caught the neanderthals in the Engineering department stealing some of our alien alloy scraps... and the morons were firing the captured alien weapons at them! Can you believe that? They called it an analysis of alien alloy's ability to absorb incoming fire, but I know that's a lie...not a single one was wearing a lab coat, and we all know real science can't happen until somebody's wearing a lab coat! Still, that shard of alien alloy was doing a pretty decent job of absorbing the abuse before it broke... I wonder if we could use that to make a new type of shield? Perhaps we could use some of the armour plating off of those Andron wrecks we've been stockpiling in the warehouse. In fact, I believe such an arrangement of alien alloys could withstand more than two hundred points of damage, if my calculations are right. I think this might work, Commander. I'll call it the Enhanced Shield, and I'll draw up the technical specifications immediately. Please make it clear to the engineers that they are to make it exactly as I say, and not to screw with me on this. My patience is wearing thin.

Here's the latest and greatest for shield tech, Commander, and not a moment too soon... The nurses at the medical center mentioned that they were treating yet another shield-bearer for panic attacks. It's as if being the designated bullet-sponge is a stressful job or something. Anyways, this new shield design should help alleviate some of the worry, as it is substantially better at absorbing incoming alien fire than it's predecessors. Our recent base upgrades, and our ability to enrich alenium, have given us access to the powerful laser cutters and plasma forges we need to be able to shape the enriched alien alloys. We still don't have a large supply of them, however, so for the time being we're going to laser weld them to a back plate of our hardest forged titanium. This should make it able to absorb five hundred and fifty points of damage before it's transformed into a crumpled ruin. A shield this protective isn't going to be light, either, but a beefy enough soldier should be able to hold it up without too much difficulty. As always, holding a shield is going to tie up one hand, so don't forget to give your soldier a nice pistol or one of our shiny new SMG models. We want our bipedal targets to feel empowered, after all.

We've finally gotten that captured Praetor to give us the technical details we need to design our own portable forcefield, and it's about time. I've been waiting for this since we first ran into these ForceShields on the battlefield, and now we're going to be able to use them to frustrate the aliens just as badly as they've been frustrating our soldiers. The technology itself is rather complicated, Commander, so feel free to stop me if I'm going too fast for you. To start with, creating a forcefield requires an enormous amount of energy, and was simply impossible to think about mere months ago...however, since then we've been introduced not only to alenium reactor technology, but also the process through which we can actually enrich alenium itself. Power is no longer an issue, even with the miniaturized reactor we have placed within the Frontal Forcefield. Our next obstacle the the projection of the field itself, and it's maintenance and reinforcement as it reacts to it's environment. This is where the alien electronics come in handy, as their superconducting properties allow us to maximize the transfer of power without having to worry about electrical resistance and heating. It's where to send the power that was the biggest hurdle, however... forcefields are notoriously unstable, and repairing the microtears that occur during every second of operation require a speed of reaction that no human can match. There is one thing that could keep up, however: an artificial intelligence, and how fortunate for us that we were able to piece one back together out of the Andron wrecks we've been hauling in from the field. With a little persuasion we've been able to get this AI to run our power controller, and it intelligently reroutes power to where it's needed as the shield takes fire, or touches the ground, or whatever. So long as the force shield matrix remains stable the shield is capable of enduring an enormous amount of punishment (750 points!), and should finally allow our shield-bearing soldiers some semblance of positive morale.

Here's what we're going to be using to get our soldiers to the downed spacecraft, Commander: The CH-48 Charlie transport helicopter. It's got enough space to get 8 of our soldiers to the field with their equipment intact, and we've armoured it up enough that it should survive the light enemy fire we expect it to recieve while deploying. Remember, that's LIGHT enemy fire... if you wind up in an air-to-air combat situation it's going to end badly for the Charlie and everyone unfortunate enough to be riding in it at a time. We've equipped it with a few reserve parachutes just in case, but I don't have to remind you that jumping out of a falling, probably burning, helicopter into a set of still-spinning rotors isn't going to be good for soldier morale...or lifespan. Don't expect everyone to make it. Also, while being extremely dependable, the CH-48 Charlie is also extraordinarily slow compared to our interceptors. It's a helicopter, not a rocket ship, so plan accordingly. Hopefully we'll have a more robust transport platform available in the near future, but for now, this is it. Keep it safe, Commander.

The D-42 Shrike is a VTOL aircraft that combines the functionality of a helicopter with the performance of a conventional aircraft. It is a major upgrade on the CH-48 Charlie, being much faster and able to carry more troops. It is also better equipped for operating in urban spaces; any mission that involves large helicopters disembarking troops in built-up areas is a recipe for disaster - indeed, it is testament to the skill of our pilots that none of our missions have begun with a bungled landing and deadly fireball.
The Shrike is a rugged, boxy creation that is as effective as it is ugly. It uses a pair of tilting TF-19 turbofan engines to cruise through the air at supersonic speeds and then perform a vertical landing on arrival at the target site. These monstrous turbines are themselves driven by two sizeable ER-12 Alenium reactors, providing enough power to keep even a fully-loaded craft airborne for days - in fact, the range limitation of the craft is due to pilot fatigue rather than fuel capacity.
However, the most important result of these new engines is a greater carrying capacity than the CH-48 Charlie. The Shrike can carry up to twelve soldiers inside its armoured troop compartment, which has large ramps at both the front and the rear to allow safer disembarkation in a hazardous landing zone. One does not need a brain as large as mine to see that bringing a quarter more soldiers into battle will significantly increase our chances of victory.

The D-54 Valkyrie Assault Boat is by far the most significant advance in dropship technology since the start of this war, and it incorporates every alien tech-enabled advance we have made so far. First of all, the A-23 Alenium Pulse reactor that I designed has such a high level of power output that we can run virtually any piece of equipment we would like... including two of the most massive turbine arrays ever assembled for use in an aircraft. This is essential, as this is also the largest troop ever developed in human history, and it's internal storage space is almost cavernous. This is going to enable two rather important improvements...for one, we going to be able to take a few more soldiers and all of their equipment. For two, we're going to be able to plant them into the battlefield via drop-pod. That's right, we have fourteen individual drop pods along the outer edges of the Valkyrie, which will allow us to precisely place our soldiers where we want them within a specific area. This means we won't have to land the Valkyrie to offload troops, keeping it out of danger. It can, of course, land at the end of the mission to pick everyone back up... wouldn't want to leave any of those wonderful alien goodies behind, would we? Back to the Valkyrie though, we've also managed to increase it's top speed considerably, so be aware of that if you are trying to time your crashed UFO assault for daylight hours. Enjoy your new toy, Commander.

Our primary X-Division interceptor, the F-17 Condor is the plane I believe will have the best chance at both catching the alien craft, and then blowing them from the sky. Of course, this opinion is based on essentially zero data, as we haven't had a chance to pit our terrestrial technology against what I assume is a vast, highly advanced alien empire before. First time for everything, I suppose. In any case, we don't have anything better to throw at them, so the F-17 will have to do. To start with, we're going to arm them with a complement of Sidewinder missiles and an X-Division autocannon, one of which should be able to do some damage to the alien craft at the very least. If we every develop something better, though, I'd upgrade the armament on these planes as soon as you can. I'd also like to mention that these planes are as heavily armoured as other modern airplanes... which is not at all. If you wind up taking alien fire, and that's an almost-certainty, our Condors are going to fall from the sky like bugs in a bug-zapper. Send them in groups if you hope to have a chance of surviving long enough to take down one of these small alien ships, or I'll be saying I told you so. Often.

You're probably wondering why I had an AWACS pulled into one of our valuable hangar bays, and the answer is simple: our radar coverage of the planet leaves a lot to be desired. Until we have a chance to put up more bases around the world to fix that situation, we're going to need a mobile radar platform to check for alien activity... and with an AWACS, we can get that job done. They've got incredible fuel economy, so we can schedule long patrols if we feel the need, but keep in mind that we achieved that amazing longevity by ditching every extra pound we could find. That includes all of the weapons and defensive measures, Commander. This plane's a sitting duck if it gets caught by an alien ship, so keep it out of harm's way or use some Condor escorts. You're call, Sir. Once we've got the worldwide radar coverage we need this plane's going to be a lot less useful, so feel free to decommission it so we can fit something more practical into that hangar. Just be aware that you're not going to be able to get your hands on another one of these planes should you sell it too soon... we didn't buy this plane, we "borrowed" it, and France is going to be mighty unhappy if they find out we took it. Best keep this our little secret, Commander.

Welcome back, Commander. Things have quite changed since your last time. Due to our logistic improvements we can now fuel aircraft 200% more quickly. On the other hand the rearm efficiency took a heavy toll and is 200% less time efficient, so you should decide wisely where to spend our precious ammuntion because its unlikely a spent aircraft will be up against the same UFO a second time. Aircraft can be launched with only 25% health and/or fuel comparing to the necessary 50% we had last time. Lastly an aircraft can be started without being fully armed. When Earth is under attack we should put up everything we have against aliens and dont be so picky about weapon armament, commander.

The MiG-32 Foxtrot is our attempt to keep our planes out of the reach of the alien plasma weaponry found on their scout ships, and I believe they'll do that job nicely... as long as your pilots aren't stupid enough to try and dogfight with them, anyways. With one torpedo hardpoint the MiG-32 has double the long-range firepower of the Condor, and will make a solid addition to our air force. I should also mention that we have heavily reinforced the airframe, so we should see more of these planes come back in one piece compared to our current send-one-lose-one Condor philosophy. Perhaps this will be enough to raise pilot morale from the current "abysmal" to the more acceptable "lukewarm"? We could certainly do with less weeping around here, that's for sure, it's ruining my afternoon nap...

Yes, Commander, I saw the petition going around... it's hard to miss when someone glues a copy to the outside window of my room. We're going to have a chat about increasing my security later, just so you know. Now, let's chat about how the pilots are complaining about all their dead friends, and how I'm supposed to somehow prevent that from happening. I've been thinking about it, and as silly as it sounds the solution is actually fairly obvious... we'll lose less pilots if less planes get shot down. Since I appear to be the only one around here that thinks operational losses are par for the course, we're going to need to build some new interceptors to keep those alien fighters off our pilot's backs. I have a few ideas about how we can put together a few of the new alien innovations to do the job, too, namely the incorporation of a new alenium reactor and the use of the semi-intelligent alien electronics. I think I can shrink all of the control and navigation software down as well, freeing up space to use for new weapons systems. In fact, I bet I could fit at least four of our autocannon systems onto one airframe, if I enlarge it a bit and beef up the engines. It would have a better top speed too...hmmm. Yes, I think that might work. I'm heading to the lab, Commander, expect to have the new blueprints by this afternoon. Project Blackwolf... it has a nice ring to it. Good day, Commander.

The X-37 Corsair is the first aircraft designed specifically for fighting extraterrestrial craft. We have made extensive use of alien materials when designing the airframe and used materials known to be resistant to alien weapons for everything else - producing an aircraft that is faster, tougher and no less agile than our F-17 Condor interceptors. It is not capable of carrying heavy torpedoes, so should complement the Foxtrot rather than replace it.
In many respects, the design of the craft is evolutionary rather than revolutionary - it is an immense undertaking to design an entire aircraft in such a short time, even for someone as intelligent as myself. Many of the gains have been made by reproducing existing systems using more efficient alien materials / manufacturing techniques, but we have made two main innovations - introduction of a variable-sweep wing design and the new ER-3 Alenium Impulsion reactor / turbine system. The latter produces twice as much thrust as a conventional jet turbine, the former increasing maneuverability at low speed while also increasing performance at high speeds. As a result, the Corsair can cruise at almost 3,000 km/h despite the extra armour making it larger and heavier than its predecessor.
Construction of each Corsair represents a significant investment of time, money and alien materials, but I have little doubt that conventional aircraft will rapidly become obsolete as the invasion escalates further.

Having heard the complaining in the pilot's quarters about my magnificent B17-X design being "obsolete ", an " old wreck ", and a "deathtrap ", I have taken it upon myself to create an even more incredible design... Behold, the B1-C Lancer! I have incorporated the alien tech into this design with stupendous results, forging the airframe from pure alien alloys to make it both lighter and stronger. The engines themselves are driven by an advanced alenium reactor of my own design, giving the new Lancer the fastest speed of any terrestrial plane to date...but that isn't what makes it so dangerous to the aliens. That honour goes to the number of weapon hardpoints I've managed to fit onto this design: two full sets of air-to-air missiles, and another full two sets of air-to-air torpedoes. If you need to engage the new, heavier alien craft at a distance, this is going to be your go-to air superiority option. Just don't try to dogfight with it, Sir... it's filled to the brim with missiles, and has no autocannons for backup. A small price to pay for the most dangerous plane in the sky, wouldn't you say?

The X-59 "Marauder " is an advanced interceptor designed to counter all known alien craft. It is fast, durable and well-armed (equipped with both a cannon and heavy torpedoes) and can perform the Combat Roll maneuver in combat. These characteristics make it just as adept at dealing with small alien interceptors as it is attacking large capital ships.
Our greatest advances in performance came from setting aside the old conventions of aircraft design. The fuselage of the Marauder contains a network of powerful integrated thrusters that provide lift and propulsion, with the stubby forward-swept wings mostly being employed for fine maneuvering. While these wings contribute heavily to the overall agility of the interceptor, it is actually entirely capable of flying without them. The same can be said for the tail / vertical stabilisers, where the traditional vertical arrangement has also been replaced with a more unusual forked design.
With few aerodynamic concerns, we have been able to focus our attention on combat performance instead. The armour plated "shell " of the craft is fabricated entirely from hardened alien materials and is nearly four inches thick in some areas, making it more akin to a flying tank than a normal interceptor. The extra engine thrust allows it to carry both a cannon and heavy torpedoes, making it a much more rounded combatant than any of its predecessors. The resulting interceptor is squat, ugly and capable of destroying almost anything it encounters (much like our engineers).

An improvement over the already-deadly F-24 Asierus, the F-32 Drake gives you more of what the F-24 did best, and increased durability as well. The F-32 features two air-to-air topedo hardpoints, giving it twice the long-range firepower of it's predecessor, perhaps even enough to seriously damage even a medium-sized alien vessel. Like the F-24 it isn't much for dogfighting, however, and will quickly fall to alien escort craft should you be silly enough to send this plane against them unescorted. Should you make such an error in judgement though, at least the increased speed and sturdier airframe might give you a chance to fly away before being too badly damaged. I don't recommend you try to find out, Commander... leave running in terror to the soldiers, they've had more practice at it.

The X-120 "Fury" interceptor is the ultimate weapon in the battle for our skies. It is an unmanned craft with virtually unlimited range that can fly so high and so fast that no UFO has a hope of outrunning it, let alone intercepting it. It can travel at Mach 8 (some 10,000 kilometers per hour), allowing it to reach any point in the world in under two hours. It carries a single super-heavy Singularity Torpedo on each mission.
The Fury was influenced by the allegedly secret SR-71 "Blackbird", which is almost invulnerable to conventional technology due to its impressive speed and service ceiling (not that our organisation would have much trouble dealing with them). The design has been evolved and enhanced, not least by removing the pilot and the equipment required to keep him alive. An autonomous flight computer tracks sensor data against mission parameters, adjusting its behaviour to ensure the mission is completed as quickly and safely as possible. The engines are a three-stage turbojet / ramjet / scramjet design where each stage speed the craft to the point at which the following stage can kick in.
The scramjets engage at Mach 4 and each produce 75,000 lbs. of thrust, rapidly accelerating the Fury to Mach 8. At these speeds air resistance heats the surface of the craft to 4,000 degrees Celsius, ordinarily impossible to sustain without a spacecraft-style ablative coating that requires replacement after every flight. However, hardened alien alloys have proved more than capable of resisting that sort of temperature indefinitely - allowing the Fury to travel so quickly that it is entirely immune to damage from enemy UFOs. Unfortunately, as weapons also need to be designed specifically for hypersonic launch, the speed of the craft also limits the weapons that can be carried to just one: the super-heavy Singularity Torpedo.
Unsurprisingly, the power requirements for these monstrous engines and the highly advanced flight computer are enormous. A Singularity Core is the only viable power source, so each Fury built will require us to capture one from an extraterrestrial capital ship.

Sir, I've had an idea that I think you're going to like... you know how we've been having such a hard time taking dows those alien capital ships, what with the incredibly dense armour and shielding and whatnot? Well, I've come up with a simple-yet-effective solution...more firepower. If we could just hit those alien ships with twice as many torpedoes I'm pretty sure we could start taking them down without the current high fatality rate, but the only planes we've got that could carry that much weight are our troop transports. As I'm sure you've noticed, they aren't exactly great at running down an alien ship... they are far too slow. There's only one plane that I'm aware of that could lift the kind of ordnance I'm thinking about while still having the speed to catch the alien capital ships... the NASA Archelon. That's right, Commander...I want to steal NASA's best bird and load it with torpedo bays. It's normally used to lift an entire space shuttle up to the edge of space, and with the same weight allowances I believe I can get four full sets of torpedoes onboard, along with all the control hardware. I also intend to cover the exterior of the plane with hardened alien alloy to give it some durability...now that I think about it, perhaps the entire skeleton of the plane should be molded from hardened alien alloys. Actually Commander, I think I'd rather steal NASA's Archelon blueprints than the plane itself... I bet we could build a better one from scratch if I can include alien tech into the design. I'll give our engineers the completed technical specifications once I've had a few hours with those blueprints. Be a pal and make the call, Commander, NASA's not going to give those blueprints up without some... encouragement.

The X-Division autocannon is a scaled up version of the M-61 Vulcan cannon, the old American Air Force standby, and is designed to give our dogfighting aircraft a chance at piercing the armoured alien hulls at close range. We are currently unsure of it's effectiveness, however, having been unable to test it against alien craft before the start of this invasion. Should the autocannon prove ineffective, perhaps our sidewinder missiles will have an effect, and if not... there's always the possibility of using the plane itself as a weapon. As the Japanese proved with their Zeroes in World War II, sometimes you have to go down with the ship if you want a ship to go down. Best of luck explaining this suicide-bombing strategy to the pilots, Commander, it should make for a lovely day!
Spear Cannon is a long ranged armour penetrating cannon for our aircrafts. The main purpose is targeting bigger ufos rather then small interceptors.
Laser cannon for our aircrafts. Short range, dog fight weapon.
Plasma blaster cannon for aircrafts. Short range, dog fight weapon.
MAG STORM cannon for aircrafts. Short range, dog fight weapon.
Wave Cannon is a long ranged armour penetrating energy beam for our aircrafts. The main purpose is targeting bigger ufos rather then small interceptors.
Very fast long range bullets against huge ufos.

The AIM-9 Sidewinder is the air-to-air missile that I feel will have the best chance at hitting the alien craft, as it can use both infrared and a limited radar system to gain a lock. All that navigation hardware doesn't leave a lot of room for explosive though, so we'll have to see how effective it is at taking down the enemy ships. If it proves ineffective, perhaps our armour-peircing autocannons will do the trick... we'll just have to try and see, Commander. As a suggestion, you may want to send out the planes equiped with this weapon in sorties of 2-3 planes... if a few missiles aren't enough to do the job, perhaps a dozen or so will.

Key information: Due to their instability you shouldnt try to equip 2 anti missile weapons on the same aircraft, otherwise it goes BOOM ... and CRASH, commander, and you dont really want the world to end like this, do you ?

The Alenium Missile is an updated version of our standard Sidewinder missile system, and we've had a chance to update more than just the explosive payload. To start with, we've been able to use the data gathered from our encounters with the alien fleet to hone in on what detection methods work best, and our new missiles are much more effective at following those signals. We've also had a chance to rework the solid-fuel rocket that powers it... since the alenium-based explosive payload actually takes up slightly less room than it's conventional predecessor, we can fit more rocket into the missile. If you look at the specs, you'll see we've been able to considerably increase it's operational range, which should keep our pilots a little further out of harm's way. We've also been able to mount fins capable of greater deflection than the previous models, allowing tighter turning during flight. All together this is a substantial upgrade, and I highly recommend you start refitting our interceptors with this technology as soon as you possible can.
Very fast, multi fired short range missile salvo launcher.

We've spent the last few days on something rather counter-intuitive, Commander, especially considering our last few plasma research projects. You see, we've been focussing on miniaturizing the alien reactor designs so that we can fit them into exeptionally small weapons like our grenades and rockets. Now that we've got more room to work with, we're finding that our reactor designs have a flaw: they are only able to convert a certain amount of alenium into energy before the cascading release of energy pushes the rest of the alenium out of the reactor. This wasn't an issue before, with such small amounts of alenium, but now that we want a bigger bang it was proving troublesome. This shouldn't have suprised me, after all the original alien reactor design was configured to convert only a small fraction of the total fuel supply at a time, a slow, controlled burn if you will. It did this by using a single laser to trigger the alenium energy release, and modulated that laser to either speed up or slow down the reaction according to the energy demand of the alien craft it powered. It was set up specifically to prevent a run-away cascade reaction, and since we just miniaturized it, so was our first designs. Not now though... our new designs incorporate multiple lasers configured spherically around the alenium. When triggered the reaction starts from all sides simultaneously, trapping the remaining alenium just long enough for it to have it's energy extracted as well. The resulting explosion is very energetic, producing a sphere of scorching plasma and high levels of ion bombardment, more than enough to leave a serious hole in the alien craft armour plating. We've also been able to incorporate a slow-burn function into the reactor design using the very principles we were fighting against with this project, and we can use this to fire a small plasma engine for this missile. It'll go further and maneuver more deftly than anything we've been able to design so far without seriously depleting the explosive core. All things considered this is quite the improvement, Commander, and should start to give us a fighting chance against the bigger alien ships we've been facing, so we'd best build some soon. Better get the monkeys back on their wrenches, Sir.

Key information: Due to their instability you shouldnt try to equip 2 anti missile weapons on the same aircraft, otherwise it goes BOOM ... and CRASH, commander, and you dont really want the world to end like this, do you ?

This is our most destructive missile yet, Commander, and not just because it contains an extremely powerful fusion warhead… though that is rather amazing, isn't it? It's actually quite the piece of technology, and it was our work with the fusion rockets and plasma missiles that made this possible. To start, we have substantially up-scaled our work on the fusion rocket, incorporating a bigger multi-laser trigger system, more alenium, and far more hydrogen. Frankly Sir, these missiles are among the most powerful fusion weapons humanity has ever built, and they should be able to put a crack in the armour of any alien vessel you can hit... and we've updated the plasma missile engines and tracking system so you should be able to hit anything you aim at. This missile flies further and faster than any missile we've ever built due to the latest refinements to the previous generation of plasma engine, and we've finally been able to start integrating some of the alien electronics into our guidance systems as well. They do the job better and require much less space than the terrestrial computers we have been relying on until now, and that added space gives us more room for explosive payload... and there's never too much room for that. All together this is a substantial upgrade, and should be rolled out to our air fleet as soon as possible.

Key information: Due to their instability you shouldnt try to equip 2 anti missile weapons on the same aircraft, otherwise it goes BOOM ... and CRASH, commander, and you dont really want the world to end like this, do you ?
Missile warheads upgrades for use of singularity.

Key information: Due to their instability you shouldnt try to equip 2 anti missile weapons on the same aircraft, otherwise it goes BOOM ... and CRASH, commander, and you dont really want the world to end like this, do you ?

The wait is over, Commander! I've finally finished the technical specifications and design schematics for our very own Alenium Torpedo, and frankly this thing's a brute. My design philosophy was simple... maximize the explosive payload first, everything else second. It won't turn quickly, it's slow, and it doesn't even track a target particularly well... but if you can get it to hit, it's game over. That's thanks to us wrapping spent Alenium around our usual high-explosive core, and lots of it... we're measuring over a 30% increase in power over the previous generation of torpedo technology. This is going to make an impact on our ability to take down the larger alien craft, and with that in mind I suggest you get on building them right now. Who knows how long we have until we start facing something our current tech can't even scratch?

I've got good news, Commander... well, good news for us, and very bad news for the alien horde. We've just finished the design of the Plasma Torpedo, and I must say we've outdone outselves... it's superior to the Alenium Torpedo in every way. We started with an analysis of the Plasma Missile technology we just got finished developing, hoping that we could scale it up without making too many changes, and for the most part this was true. Our bigger, badder torpedo design uses the same multi-laser alenium reactor design that the missile does, just scaled up to fit most of the available room within the torpedo housing. It's not all sunshine and rainbows though, as the size of the reactor is such that weight has become quite a factor... in short, this torpedo is very, very heavy. Even with the new plasma engine designs we can't move this much weight that quickly, so even though it's at least faster than the alenium torpedo it's replacing it's not going to be breaking an speed records anytime soon. We have managed to make it turn a little better as well, which is some consolation, but I'm just not willing to sacrifice room for payload in order to fit a better guidance computer on to it. So long as your pilots line up their shots like they did with the alenium torpedoes, it should work fine. Time to get refitting, Commander.
With power of the anti-gravity generator, we can create a little black hole at the target zone.

We've finally done it Commander, we've figured out how to scale up our fusion missile technology to torpedo levels… and it wasn't easy, I assure you. Most of the difficulty came from our attempts to simply add more alenium and hydrogen to a bigger reactor, but instead of giving us the bigger, better explosion we were hoping for this method gave us bombs that fizzled out. Don't get me wrong, they still exploded, but the yield was far less than it should be given the amount of fuel we included. We eventually figured out that it was the sheer mass of the reactant that was the problem... it was simply impossible to start an alenium reaction that big and keep it not only perfectly centered in the reactor, but have it react at exactly the same rate all the way to the center. The reaction inevitably became lopsided and blew out one of the sides of the reactor before the hydrogen could be sufficiently compressed to fuse. We needed a new strategy... and what we came up with was rather simple: we have a working fusion missile design, why not just include two copies of the fusion core in the torpedo housing and spend our time and effort finding a way to simultaneously detonate them? Which we did, by the way, though the control circuitry took up some of the room we
This singularity warheads can also be used to upgrade the torpedoes carried by our bombers.
All the technology we got is combined with this ultra destroying torpedo. One shot, one kill..

Good evening commander. When you tasked my team with creating a vehicle that could withstand the outrageous stresses of the ET's small arms fire, I thought you to be insane. Creating any vessel that would disperse the immense heat created by an energy bolt of that degree was a very far fetched proposition, but that's why you hired us... to achieve marvelous feats of science fiction. Unfortunately... my R&D team was unable to be very original and stole some British schematics for a light, anti-personnel vehicle (a Daimler Ferret armored car) and altered a few various components. While most of the new modifications are superficial accommodations for the vehicle's crew (cup holders, A/C etc.), there is one new radical idea that my team has applied to the vehicle's hull: Tungsten.
The vehicle's outer layers, initially, were very flimsy and weak only providing about 1 cm of steel as buffer, which was made to withstand our primitive ballistic weaponry. Since the vehicle's original armor would never resist a single shot from the heat projected by an ET's pistol, the team decided an upgrade was extremely necessary. We eventually came to the conclusion that a composite layering of tungsten would be the best option for preventing penetration of the armor because of it's outrageous melting point.
Unfortunately, due to the nature of the vehicle, it is unable to carry much more than 2 30mm cannons (with very limited ammo) for weight reasons, respectively. On the upside, we could always be a bit more... pragmatic, and engineer some less conventional armaments for more precarious situations (this invasion will be full of them, obviously). In reality I'm thinking about propositions such as scaling down our aircraft torpedoes and mounting several pods on the car, adapting a flamethrower, or even testing the results of engineering (or adapting) chemical weapons for use against the ET forces.
Also, as a final thought commander, I would try to steer clear of using this vehicle once we inevitably get a new, more suitable, combat based replacement (likely using technology discovered through alien tech). Also, as I am currently pending the success of a motorized division in defense of earth, I am drawing up some, although basic, schematics that could serve as future vehicles. Although, at this rate a composite tungsten layering will not be enough.

We at the R&D team really struck gold this time, commander. To supplement your needs for an updated anti-personnel vehicle, we decided to blatantly plagiarize ... again. Although this time, the resulting product stems from more classified means. Using my ubiquitous list of contacts over in Britain, I was able to redeem a few favors ... A few quarters and a payphone later, crudely drawn schematics and a few other related documents "spontaneously" appeared on my desk. The enclosed documents entailed a few different options, two of which being of note, the first, a FV102 Scimitar (A light battle tank currently in use by the Britain's armed forces) and, more importantly, a FV510 Warrior (A British prototype vehicle in the end stages of development).
The choice between the two, ultimately, ended in a criteria favoring the Warrior, because of the potential use of adapting the sizable troop transport compartment for out own nefarious purposes. There were only a few minor problems, excluding the fact that vehicle's weight (which originally was about twenty five thousand kilograms) was far too great for any reasonable insertion craft at our disposal. To counteract this my team was tasked in altering components or removing redundant ones altogether. The end result had a decreased range (not like we need it to go very far), a lowered max speed (still can outpace most aliens), and very basic environmental protection equipment (replaced the lead lining with a composite of our wonder material: tungsten).
The end result has been deemed the Defender by the R&D team because of it having a far more robust physique than its precursor the Hunter. Although it is labeled as a direct upgrade to the Hunter scout, it is far more of an alternate choice. Where if you would prefer to stick to a hit-and-run tactic when using a combat vehicle, the hunter would make a far superior choice, while if you want something to absorb blows while your team advances, this is the vehicle for you.
Of course I feel like there is a need to remind you, commander, that it is likely that anything we ever make will be completely retardant to whatever the ET's weapons are capable of, but we can most certainly improve. I would recommend capturing (as opposed to incinerating) as many devices the ETs may have that would further our understanding of ET technology to give us the best fighting chance.

…Summary…
Damage: 150 Type: Incendiary Mitigation: 0 The "Viper" rocket rack is an alternate turret option for the Hunter scout car, substantially increasing the vehicle's firepower by replacing the dual .30cal machineguns with eight high-explosive rockets.
These rockets are repurposed air-to-air missiles that lack much of a fragmentation effect, but will still inflict heavy incendiary damage across a large area. Though best suited to demolishing structures, they should still make short work of our weaker alien foes. However, there are two major disadvantages to this - firstly, the rockets are so large that the Hunter can only carry eight of them into battle. Secondly, explosives are a poor way to obtain recoverable alien technology. It is unlikely that we will be able to recover anything of value from the corpses of any enemies killed by these rockets.
Nevertheless, there are many occasions where the loss of a few artefacts would be preferable to the loss of one or more of our soldiers. If you wish to equip a Hunter with the Viper, the upgraded turrets have already been made available in the Garage.

…Summary…
Damage: 30 Type: kinetic Mitigation: 5 The dual .30cal machineguns

…Summary…
